name.#text: Has the DAC6 been implemented?
Reporting deferral

p.#text: Yes, 6 months

name.#text: Effective date
Was the transitory regime of Council Directive (EU) 2020/876 incorporated into domestic legislation?

p.#text: of 26 June 2020, published in the Official Gazette no. 35240 of 26 June 2020, amending Decree 12560 of 16 June 2020 (

emph.#text: Fiscale tegemoetkomingen naar aanleiding van de coronacrisis; (Besluit noodmaatregelen coronacrisis). Wijziging van het besluit van 16 juni 2020, nr.2020-12560)

p.#text: , published in Official Gazette No. 2020,33211.

name.#text: Is there a specific definition provided by the domestic legislation?
Have the definitions of articles 3(18) and 3(19) of the DAC been incorporated into domestic legislation?

p.#text: Explicit reference to those articles of the DAC (article 2d(1)(a) and (b) of the WIB.

name.#text: Are there significant deviations from the DAC on the definitions provided by the domestic legislation?
Has the definition of article 3(20) of the DAC been incorporated into domestic legislation?

p.#text: Explicit reference to that article of the DAC (article 2d(1)(c) of the WIB.

name.#text: Are there significant deviations from the DAC definition provided by the domestic legislation?
Are the hallmarks covered by the domestic legislation the same as in Annex IV Part II of the DAC?

p.#text: Reference to Annex IV of the DAC (article 2d(1)(c) of the WIB.

name.#text: Has the definition of article 3(23) of the DAC been incorporated into domestic legislation?

p.#text: Explicit reference to that article of the DAC (article 2d(1)(f) of the WIB.

name.#text: Are there significant deviations from the DAC definition provided by the domestic legislation?

p.#text: Article 10a (4)-(7) of the Corporate Income Tax Law of 1969 (

) contains a definition of associated ("connected") persons which – generally speaking – provides for a threshold of 33.33%. No specific DAC-related definition is present other than the reference to the article 3(23) of the DAC.

name.#text: Has the definition of article 3(24) of the DAC been incorporated into domestic legislation?

p.#text: Explicit reference to that article of the DAC (article 2d(1)(g) of the WIB.

name.#text: Are there significant deviations from the DAC definition provided by the domestic legislation?
Has the definition of Part I of the Annex IV of the DAC been incorporated into domestic legislation?

p.#text: Second paragraph of Part I of the Annex IV has been transposed into domestic law (article 2d(2) of the WIB.

name.#text: Are there significant deviations from the DAC definition provided by the domestic legislation?
Is there a specific definition provided by the domestic legislation?

p.#text: Reference to Part 4.7 of the

url.#text: Commission Recommendation of 6 December 2012 on aggressive tax planning (2012/772/EU) by the explanatory memorandum

p.#text: to the
where a set of criteria is listed that can be used when determining whether an arrangement (or series thereof) has led to a tax advantage.

name.#text: Has the definition of article 3(11) of the DAC been implemented into domestic legislation?

p.#text: Article 2(n) of the WIB.
Residence: article 2(a), 2and 3 of the WIB. Participant: article 2(1)(d) of the WIB.

title.#text: Category A: Generic hallmarks linked to the main benefit test
Category A.1.: Arrangements with confidentiality clauses for their participants

name.#text: Has this Hallmark been implemented into domestic legislation?

p.#text: Reference to Annex IV of the DAC (article 2d(1)(c) of the WIB.

name.#text: Key insights from the legislation and/or guidance

p.#text: , at section 6.1.1.

The disclosure of confidential information will, in principle, not be an issue in the Netherlands as confidentiality arrangements included in the general terms and conditions of an advice cannot prevent the client/relevant taxpayer from – upon request – providing the Tax Authority with information regarding the arrangement due to the latter's investigatory powers.

title.#text: Category A.2.: Arrangements with performance-based remunerations for intermediaries

name.#text: Has this Hallmark been implemented into domestic legislation?

p.#text: Reference to Annex IV of the DAC (article 2d(1)(c) of the WIB.

name.#text: Key insights from the legislation and/or guidance

name.#text: Has this Hallmark been implemented into domestic legislation?

p.#text: Reference to Annex IV of the DAC (article 2d(1)(c) of the WIB.

name.#text: Key insights from the legislation and/or guidance

p.#text: The explanatory memorandum to the implementing law notes that this hallmark does not, for example, apply to certain, standard banking products.

p.#text: The
to the
notes that legal acts such as those described in article 10a(1) of the
(use of loans from a related party for a tainted transactions) is a reportable example under this hallmark.
For the White/blacklisted examples for this Hallmark, see

title.#text: Category C: Specific hallmarks related to cross-border transactions
Category C.1.: Arrangements involving deductions of cross-border payments between associated enterprises

name.#text: Has this Hallmark been implemented into domestic legislation?

p.#text: Reference to Annex IV of the DAC (article 2d(1)(c) of the WIB.

name.#text: Key insights from the legislation and/or guidance

p.#text: The
to the
notes:
"...the rate of zero or almost zero..." refers to a statutory rate between 0% and 1% ;

-	Hallmark C.1, under c), refers to an objective exemption, and not a subjective exemption. Under an objective exemption certain types of payments are generally exempt from tax, while under a subjective exemption only certain categories of taxpayers are exempt;

Hallmark C.1, under d), "...a preferential tax regime..."  is broader than harmful tax regime, and includes, for example the Dutch innovation box and the tonnage tax regime. This in itself does not mean that application of the regime passes the main benefit test.
For the White/blacklisted examples for this Hallmark, see here.

title.#text: Category C.2.: Arrangements involving multiple deductions for the depreciation of the same asset in different jurisdictions

name.#text: Has this Hallmark been implemented into domestic legislation?

p.#text: Reference to Annex IV of the DAC (article 2d(1)(c) of the WIB.

name.#text: Key insights from the legislation and/or guidance

p.#text: The
to the
notes that this hallmark also applies to situations where both the permanent establishment and the head office claim the same deduction.
For the White/blacklisted examples for this Hallmark, see here.

title.#text: Category C.3.: Arrangements involving multiple reliefs from double taxation for the same item of income or capital in different jurisdictions

name.#text: Has this Hallmark been implemented into domestic legislation?

p.#text: Reference to Annex IV of the DAC (article 2d(1)(c) of the WIB.

name.#text: Key insights from the legislation and/or guidance

p.#text: notes that this Hallmark only applies cases where effectively no tax is paid on the income or asset.

title.#text: Category C.4.: Arrangements including significant differences on the value of assets transferred between different jurisdictions

name.#text: Has this Hallmark been implemented into domestic legislation?

p.#text: Reference to Annex IV of the DAC (article 2d(1)(c) of the WIB.

name.#text: Key insights from the legislation and/or guidance

p.#text: The explanatory memorandum to the implementing law notes that
"transfer" also encompasses allocation of the asset between a permanent establishment and the head office; and
"consideration" also encompasses "amounts owed".
For the White/blacklisted examples for this Hallmark, see here.

title.#text: Category D: Specific hallmarks concerning automatic exchange of information and beneficial ownership
Category D.1.: Arrangements undermining reporting obligations under agreements for the automatic exchange of information

name.#text: Has this Hallmark been implemented into domestic legislation?

p.#text: Reference to Annex IV of the DAC (article 2d(1)(c) of the WIB.

name.#text: Key insights from the legislation and/or guidance

p.#text: The
to the
notes that this hallmark covers the (frustration of) exchange of information on the basis of the Common Report Standard (CRS), but not (yet) FATCA.

title.#text: Category D.2.: Arrangements involving non-transparent legal/beneficial ownership chains by using offshore entities or structures not carrying substantive economic activities

name.#text: Has this Hallmark been implemented into domestic legislation?

p.#text: Reference to Annex IV of the DAC (article 2d(1)(c) of the WIB.

name.#text: Key insights from the legislation and/or guidance

p.#text: , at section 6.4.1. notes that – in line with the article 1.2(c) of the Model Mandatory Disclosure Rules for CRS Avoidance Arrangements and Opaque Offshore Structures (OECD), institutional investors and other persons fully held by one or more institutional investors are not deemed to hide the ultimate effective control.

name.#text: How is the legal professional privilege defined in the domestic legislation?

p.#text: Religious leaders, notaries, lawyers, doctors and pharmacists may invoke this privilege.
Article 10h(5) of the WIB refers to article 53a of the General Income Tax Act.

p.#text: Article 3(22) of the DAC (article 2d(1)(e) of the WIB).

How does the person liable to report file a DAC6 return?

p.#text: The arrangement must be filed through a

url.#text: dedicated portal of the Dutch Tax and Customs Authority

p.#text: This video gives a basic demonstration of the portal (the audio is Dutch, but the portal itself is English).

name.#text: Tax authorities' contact details

p.#text: A contact page of the Tax Authority is available
For questions relating to the mandatory disclosure regime itself (e.g. the hallmarks), as well as the forms on the data portal, an email can be sent to:

name.#text: Does the information to be communicated follow article 8ab(14) of the DAC?

p.#text: Article 10h(2) of the WIB. Article 2a(6) of the WIB notes that "TIN" also encompasses any functional equivalent thereof.

name.#text: What are the failures to comply with the obligations laid down in the DAC as amended by the DAC6 covered and the penalties assigned to them?

p.#text: The maximum penalty that may be imposed is set at EUR 870,000 in case the intermediary or relevant taxpayer intentionally – or as a result of gross negligence (i) does not; (ii) not in a timely manner; (iii) incompletely; or (iv) incorrectly fulfil the obligations set out in the relevant articles (article 11(2) of the WIB). Lower fines may be levied depending on the seriousness of the violation.
The
to the

notes that the penalty provision also applies to an intermediary who invokes his legal privilege but does not inform the other intermediaries or relevant taxpayers (as the case may be) of their obligations in these situations.
